bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Harold W. Jones, February 12, 1942

div1.p: Hench discusses a possible abstract of his yellow fever paper that Jones might publish.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Harold W. Jones, February 12, 1942
div1.opener:
Y F.
February 12, 1942
Colonel Harold W. Jones
Army Medical Library
Washington, D. C.
My dear Colonel Jones:
div1.p:
I received your letter of January 8 commenting on the suggestion of
Mr. Keys of the Mayo Clinic Library that I submit to you a paper for the
Bulletin of the Medical Library Association. Instead of answering it, I
took it with me to Washington as I was going there a few days later. Un-
fortunately, I visited your office when you were away for a day or so with
a bad cold, I believe. I saw Dr. Mayer and asked that he tell you of my
call. I didn't really know whether you will want what I have to offer or not.

By separate post, I am sending you a reprint of a yellow fever story
which I recently wrote. This is in connection with the Wyeth painting on the
“Conquerors of Yellow Fever”. Prior to the decision to paint the final version
of the painting as illustrated in my reprint, two Cuban versions of this paint-
ing were made. These original paintings now are in our library here. The
Wyeth people had colored plates made of them but have not used them. I enclose
illustrations of them in the size of prints which are available. Mr. Keys
suggested that I make a brief abstract of the paper which I have already pub-
lished and illustrate it with one or two of these Cuban versions of the paint-
ing. I am given to believe that you may not be especially interested in any
abstract of a paper already published even though it is illustrated by un-
published plates, but if you are, I shall be glad to cooperate.

Mr. Kellogg, who was responsible for these colored plates says they
will be very glad to lend you the plates although they hardly feel justified in
printing the colored inserts and giving them to you gratis. Let me make myself
clear. They will be glad to lend you the plates gratis if you wish to make use
of them. Please feel frank to tell me what you think. In any event, I should
appreciate if you would return the colored illustrations to me as they are the
only ones I have.
div1.closer: Very truly yours, P. S. Hench, M. D. psh:ds
